importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article update indicates the current status of the postseason as of Friday, October 17, 2025, showing the timeline of the NLCS and ALCS progress.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame represents the critical window in which the Dodgers are one win away from a second consecutive World Series appearance and the Blue Jays are tied in the ALCS, creating a pivotal moment in MLB postseason history.

keyTakeAways: The Los Angeles Dodgers are one game away from securing a second consecutive World Series appearance after defeating the Milwaukee Brewers 3-1 in Game 4 of the NLCS.
The Dodgers have an 8-1 postseason record, with their only loss being to the Philadelphia Phillies in the NLDS, indicating strong performance in the playoffs.
The Dodgers now lead the NLCS 3-0, a significant advantage historically, as only the Boston Red Sox in 2004 have won a best-of-seven series after losing the first three games.
The Toronto Blue Jays have tied the Seattle Mariners in the ALCS after outscoring them 21-6 in Games 3 and 4, making them a strong contender to advance to the World Series.
Max Scherzer, aged 41, delivered a strong performance in Game 4 of the ALCS, allowing only two runs and three hits in 5 2/3 innings, highlighting veteran leadership and resilience.
Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hit his fifth home run of the playoffs, contributing to the Blue Jays' momentum in the ALCS.
The Blue Jays have won each of the first four games as a road team in the ALCS, maintaining a strong home-field advantage in terms of momentum.
The Dodgers' potential second straight World Series appearance would be historic, as no team has done so since the Yankees’ three-peat from 1998 to 2000.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball (MLB) team based in Los Angeles, competing in the National League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers are in the process of securing a second consecutive World Series appearance, which would be a historic achievement in MLB history, making them one of the most dominant teams in recent postseason history.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball (MLB) team based in Milwaukee, competing in the National League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers are the opposing team in the NLCS, and the Dodgers' 3-1 lead puts them on the cusp of a World Series berth, showing a significant shift in playoff momentum.

namedEntities.name: Philadelphia Phillies
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball (MLB) team based in Philadelphia, competing in the National League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Phillies were the last team to win back-to-back World Series in 2009, serving as a historical benchmark for the Dodgers' achievement of a second straight appearance.

namedEntities.name: Boston Red Sox
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball (MLB) team based in Boston, competing in the American League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Red Sox are referenced as the only team to win a best-of-seven series after losing the first three games, which underscores the rarity and significance of the Dodgers’ 3-0 lead in the NLCS.

namedEntities.name: New York Yankees
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball (MLB) team based in New York, competing in the American League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Yankees are referenced as the last team to win back-to-back World Series (1998–2000), setting the historical context for why the Dodgers' potential achievement is so rare and significant.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball (MLB) team based in Toronto, competing in the American League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are tied with the Seattle Mariners in the ALCS, showing that the path to the World Series is still uncertain and competitive, adding a layer of unpredictability to the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball (MLB) team based in Seattle, competing in the American League.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are facing the Blue Jays in the ALCS and are currently trailing 2-0, with the Blue Jays tying the series after strong offensive performances in Games 3 and 4.

namedEntities.name: Max Scherzer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 41-year-old former MLB pitcher, currently playing for the Toronto Blue Jays in the postseason.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Scherzer delivered a crucial performance in Game 4 of the ALCS, allowing only two runs and three hits in 5 2/3 innings, showcasing veteran leadership and resilience in a pivotal moment.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Guerrero Jr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball player for the Toronto Blue Jays, known for his power hitting.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Guerrero Jr. hit his fifth home run of the playoffs, contributing significantly to the Blue Jays' offensive surge in Games 3 and 4 of the ALCS.

namedEntities.name: Tommy Edman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball player for the Los Angeles Dodgers, known for his bat and base-running skills.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Edman drove in the run that gave the Dodgers a lead in the sixth inning and expressed excitement about the team's momentum and proximity to a World Series appearance.

namedEntities.name: Freddie Freeman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball player for the Los Angeles Dodgers, known for his hitting and offensive contributions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Freeman scored on a throwing error from Abner Uribe, helping the Dodgers take a 3-1 lead in the game and move closer to a World Series berth.

namedEntities.name: Abner Uribe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Major League Baseball player for the Milwaukee Brewers, known for his defensive contributions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Uribe committed a throwing error that allowed Freddie Freeman to score, a pivotal moment in the Dodgers’ 3-1 win over the Brewers.

namedEntities.name: Jacob Misiorowski
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Milwaukee Brewers pitcher, a rookie in the postseason.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Misiorowski struck out nine batters, setting a Milwaukee rookie postseason record, and contributed to a tight game in the first five innings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Los Angeles Dodgers are one win away from achieving a second consecutive World Series appearance after a 3-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers in Game 4 of the NLCS, now leading 3-0 with a strong postseason record. This milestone would make them the first defending champion to reach the World Series in 16 years, following the Yankees' three-peat from 1998 to 2000. Meanwhile, in the ALCS, the Toronto Blue Jays have tied the Seattle Mariners after outscoring them 21-6 in Games 3 and 4, with Max Scherzer and Vladimir Guerrero Jr. playing pivotal roles. The Blue Jays now have momentum and a chance to advance, while the Dodgers’ path to the World Series remains highly probable, making this a pivotal moment in MLB postseason history.
title: Dodgers close in on second straight World Series appearance, Blue Jays knot up ALCS against Mariners
